description: Extended RadLex Radiology Lexicon - Comprehensive Chest CT Terminology

entries.title: Acinus
entries.content: The functional unit of the lung supplied by a single terminal bronchiole. Contains respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, alveolar sacs, and alveoli. Multiple acini form a secondary pulmonary lobule.

entries.title: Air Bronchiologram
entries.content: Air-filled bronchioles visible within an area of ground-glass opacity or consolidation. Smaller caliber than air bronchogram. Indicates patent small airways with surrounding alveolar pathology.

entries.title: Air Trapping
entries.content: Retention of air in the lung distal to an obstruction, seen as areas of decreased attenuation on expiratory CT. Indicates small airways disease. Quantified by expiratory/inspiratory attenuation ratio.

entries.title: Airspace Disease
entries.content: Pathologic process involving the alveolar airspaces, manifesting as consolidation or ground-glass opacity on CT. Includes pneumonia, pulmonary edema, hemorrhage, and neoplasia.

entries.title: Anterior Junction Line
entries.content: A thin vertical line on frontal chest imaging where the two lungs approximate anteriorly, between the sternum and great vessels. Normal variant, should not be confused with pathology.

entries.title: Aortopulmonary Window
entries.content: Mediastinal space bounded by the aortic arch superiorly, pulmonary artery inferiorly, and mediastinal pleura laterally. Contains lymph nodes (station 5). Enlargement of nodes here is significant.

entries.title: Apical Cap
entries.content: Focal opacity at the lung apex. May represent pleural thickening, extrapleural fat, or apical scar. Asymmetric or growing apical cap should raise concern for Pancoast tumor.

entries.title: Architectural Distortion
entries.content: Abnormal displacement of bronchi, vessels, fissures, or septa from their normal anatomic position. Indicates fibrosis or scarring. May be associated with traction bronchiectasis.

entries.title: Atoll Sign
entries.content: See Reversed Halo Sign. A focal rounded area of ground-glass opacity surrounded by a ring or crescent of consolidation. Originally described in organizing pneumonia.

entries.title: Azygos Fissure
entries.content: Anomalous fissure in the right upper lobe created by aberrant lateral position of the azygos vein during development. Contains four layers of pleura. Normal variant, no clinical significance.

entries.title: Bat Wing Distribution
entries.content: Bilateral perihilar airspace disease sparing the periphery, creating a butterfly or bat wing appearance. Classic for cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Also seen in Pneumocystis pneumonia.

entries.title: Beaded Septum Sign
entries.content: Irregular nodular thickening of interlobular septa, giving a beaded appearance. Characteristic of lymphangitic carcinomatosis. Differs from smooth septal thickening of edema.

entries.title: Bleb
entries.content: Small (<1cm) cystic airspace within or just beneath the visceral pleura. Often found at lung apices. May rupture to cause spontaneous pneumothorax.

entries.title: Bronchial Atresia
entries.content: Congenital abnormality with obliteration of a segmental or subsegmental bronchus. CT shows focal bronchocele (mucoid impaction) with surrounding hyperinflated lung from collateral ventilation.

entries.title: Bronchocele
entries.content: Mucus-filled dilated bronchus. Appears as tubular or branching structure of soft tissue or fluid attenuation. Causes include bronchial atresia, obstruction, and ABPA.

entries.title: Bronchovascular Bundle Thickening
entries.content: Abnormal thickening of the peribronchovascular interstitium surrounding the bronchovascular bundles. Seen in sarcoidosis, lymphangitic carcinomatosis, and pulmonary edema.

entries.title: Bulla
entries.content: Emphysematous space >1cm in diameter with thin (<1mm) wall. May occur in paraseptal emphysema, post-infectious, or idiopathic. Giant bullae can occupy significant lung volume.

entries.title: Calcified Granuloma
entries.content: Completely calcified nodule representing healed granulomatous infection (histoplasmosis, TB). Benign finding. May have central, diffuse, or laminated calcification pattern.

entries.title: Carina
entries.content: The cartilaginous ridge at the bifurcation of the trachea into the right and left main bronchi. Normally at T5-T6 level. Widening or distortion indicates subcarinal pathology.

entries.title: Carinal Angle
entries.content: The angle formed by the right and left main bronchi at the carina. Normal angle is 60-100 degrees. Widening (>90-100 degrees) may indicate subcarinal mass or left atrial enlargement.

entries.title: Cavity
entries.content: Gas-filled space within a pulmonary nodule, mass, or area of consolidation. Distinguished from cyst by thicker wall (>4mm). Seen in infection, malignancy, and vasculitis.

entries.title: Central Dot Sign
entries.content: A pulmonary artery seen as a dot within a dilated bronchus on cross-section in bronchiectasis. Represents the normal-sized artery within the abnormally dilated bronchus.

entries.title: Centrilobular
entries.content: Located in the center of the secondary pulmonary lobule, around the centrilobular artery and bronchiole. Centrilobular nodules are separated from pleura by several millimeters.

entries.title: Comet Tail Sign
entries.content: Curved band of atelectatic lung tissue and vessels extending from a rounded atelectasis to the hilum. Resembles a comet tail. Pathognomonic for rounded atelectasis.

entries.title: Costophrenic Angle
entries.content: The angle formed by the chest wall and diaphragm at the lateral lung base. Normally sharp on frontal imaging. Blunting indicates pleural effusion or thickening.

entries.title: CT Angiogram Sign
entries.content: Enhancement of pulmonary vessels within a low-attenuation mass or consolidation on contrast CT. Suggests neoplasm (especially mucinous adenocarcinoma) rather than infection.

entries.title: Cylindrical Bronchiectasis
entries.content: Mild form of bronchiectasis with uniform dilation of the bronchus without significant tapering. The mildest form of bronchiectatic change.

entries.title: Cyst
entries.content: A rounded, circumscribed space with thin wall (<2mm) containing air or fluid. Distinguished from cavity by thin wall. Causes include LAM, LIP, PLCH, and infection.

entries.title: Cystic Bronchiectasis
entries.content: Severe form of bronchiectasis with saccular or cystic dilation of bronchi, often with air-fluid levels. The most severe form of bronchiectatic change.

entries.title: Dependent Opacity
entries.content: Increased attenuation in dependent (posterior when supine) lung regions. May be physiologic (gravity-dependent atelectasis) or pathologic. Prone imaging distinguishes the two.

entries.title: Diffuse Alveolar Damage (DAD)
entries.content: Histopathologic pattern of acute lung injury. CT shows diffuse GGO and consolidation. Seen in ARDS, acute interstitial pneumonia, and drug toxicity.

entries.title: Double Bronchial Wall Sign
entries.content: Visualization of both walls of a bronchus, indicating bronchial wall thickening. Normal bronchial wall should be imperceptible except at perpendicular angles.

entries.title: Eggshell Calcification
entries.content: Calcification in a ring-like pattern in the periphery of lymph nodes. Classic for silicosis and coal worker's pneumoconiosis. Can also be seen in sarcoidosis and post-radiation.

entries.title: Expiratory CT
entries.content: CT images obtained at end-expiration. Used to detect air trapping, which appears as areas of persistent low attenuation compared to inspiratory images.

entries.title: Fat Attenuation
entries.content: CT attenuation in the range of -40 to -120 HU, indicating fat content. In pulmonary nodules, suggests hamartoma or lipoid pneumonia. Also seen in mediastinal lipomatosis.

entries.title: Feeding Vessel
entries.content: A pulmonary artery leading directly to a nodule, mass, or area of consolidation. Suggests hematogenous origin such as septic embolism or metastasis.

entries.title: Finger-in-Glove Sign
entries.content: Tubular or branching opacities representing mucoid impaction in dilated bronchi. Shaped like fingers of a glove. Classic for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

entries.title: Fleischner Criteria
entries.content: Guidelines for management of incidentally detected pulmonary nodules published by the Fleischner Society. Based on nodule size, type, and patient risk factors.

entries.title: Focal Lucency
entries.content: Localized area of decreased attenuation within the lung. May represent emphysema, cyst, cavity, or air trapping. Context and morphology determine significance.

entries.title: Galaxy Sign
entries.content: A large nodule or mass surrounded by multiple smaller satellite nodules. Classic for sarcoidosis. The central lesion and satellites have perilymphatic distribution.

entries.title: Ground-Glass Attenuation
entries.content: See Ground-Glass Opacity. Area of hazy increased lung attenuation through which normal structures remain visible. Does not obscure underlying vasculature.

entries.title: Head Cheese Sign
entries.content: Geographic areas of three different attenuations in the lung: normal, ground-glass (infiltrative disease), and low attenuation (air trapping). Named after the meat product with mixed colors.

entries.title: Hepatization
entries.content: Dense consolidation of the lung that resembles liver on CT (similar attenuation). Indicates complete alveolar filling. Classic in lobar pneumonia.

entries.title: Hilar Overlay Sign
entries.content: Preservation of the normal hilar structures through an apparent hilar mass, indicating the mass is actually anterior or posterior to the hilum, not within it.

entries.title: Hounsfield Unit (HU)
entries.content: Unit of measurement for CT attenuation. Water = 0 HU, air = -1000 HU, bone = +1000 HU. Used to characterize tissue composition.

entries.title: Incomplete Fissure
entries.content: Absence of part of the pulmonary fissure, allowing direct communication between adjacent lobes. May facilitate spread of disease between lobes.

entries.title: Interface Sign
entries.content: Irregular interface between lung and mediastinum, pleura, or vessels. Indicates parenchymal abnormality (fibrosis, inflammation) at the interface.

entries.title: Interlobular Septum
entries.content: The thin connective tissue boundary of the secondary pulmonary lobule containing pulmonary veins and lymphatics. Thickening indicates edema, fibrosis, or lymphangitic spread.

entries.title: Juxtaphrenic Peak
entries.content: Triangular shadow at the diaphragm apex seen with upper lobe volume loss. Created by upward traction on the inferior accessory fissure or the inferior pulmonary ligament.

entries.title: Kerley A Lines
entries.content: Long (2-6cm) linear opacities in the upper lungs representing thickened deep interlobular septa or connective tissue around bronchovascular bundles. Seen in pulmonary edema.

entries.title: Kerley B Lines
entries.content: Short (1-2cm) horizontal lines at the lung bases perpendicular to the pleural surface representing thickened interlobular septa. Classic for pulmonary edema.

entries.title: Lingula
entries.content: Tongue-like projection of the left upper lobe, homologous to the right middle lobe. Bounded by the major fissure posteriorly. Has superior and inferior segments.

entries.title: Lobular Core
entries.content: The center of the secondary pulmonary lobule containing the centrilobular artery and bronchiole. Centrilobular abnormalities affect this region.

entries.title: Lobar Collapse
entries.content: Complete atelectasis of a pulmonary lobe. Each lobe has characteristic pattern of collapse with specific fissural displacement and mediastinal shift.

entries.title: Luftsichel Sign
entries.content: Crescent of hyperinflated superior segment of lower lobe interposed between the aorta and collapsed upper lobe. Sign of left upper lobe collapse.

entries.title: Lung Density
entries.content: The CT attenuation of lung parenchyma. Normal lung is approximately -850 to -700 HU. Increased density (less negative) indicates GGO or consolidation.

entries.title: Lymphangitic Carcinomatosis
entries.content: Tumor spread through pulmonary lymphatics. CT shows thickened interlobular septa (smooth or nodular), bronchovascular bundle thickening, and preserved lung architecture.

entries.title: Main Bronchus
entries.content: The primary bronchus on each side arising from the tracheal bifurcation. Right main bronchus is shorter, wider, and more vertical than left.

metadata.anatomic_note: Right is shorter and more vertical

entries.title: Mediastinal Compartment
entries.content: Division of mediastinum into anterior, middle, and posterior compartments. Location of mass helps narrow differential diagnosis.

entries.title: Mediastinal Fat Stranding
entries.content: Increased attenuation and haziness in mediastinal fat, indicating inflammation, edema, or infiltration. May be seen with mediastinitis or post-procedural changes.

entries.title: Mediastinal Window
entries.content: CT display window optimized for soft tissue visualization (typically W350 L40). Used to evaluate mediastinum, lymph nodes, and solid components of nodules.

entries.title: Miliary Pattern
entries.content: Innumerable tiny (1-3mm) nodules uniformly distributed throughout both lungs. Random distribution suggests hematogenous spread. Classic for miliary TB and metastases.

entries.title: Mucoid Impaction
entries.content: Mucus plugging within bronchi appearing as tubular or branching opacities. Seen in ABPA, bronchial obstruction, cystic fibrosis, and asthma.

entries.title: Nodular Septal Thickening
entries.content: Beaded or nodular appearance of thickened interlobular septa. Characteristic of lymphangitic carcinomatosis and sarcoidosis. Distinguished from smooth thickening in edema.

entries.title: Nodule Enhancement
entries.content: Increase in CT attenuation of a nodule after IV contrast. Enhancement >15HU suggests vascularity and favors malignancy over benign nodule.

entries.title: Obstructive Atelectasis
entries.content: Lung collapse due to bronchial obstruction (tumor, mucus plug, foreign body). Air absorbed from obstructed segment. May have associated post-obstructive pneumonia.

entries.title: Panacinar Emphysema
entries.content: See Panlobular Emphysema. Uniform destruction involving the entire acinus. Associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. Lower lobe predominant.

entries.title: Paraseptal Emphysema
entries.content: Emphysematous changes located along interlobular septa and pleura. Often subpleural. May lead to bullae and spontaneous pneumothorax.

entries.title: Parenchymal Band
entries.content: Non-tapering linear opacity 2-5cm long extending to the pleura. Represents fibrotic scar, atelectasis, or lymphatic tissue. Common in asbestos-related disease.

entries.title: Peripheral Distribution
entries.content: Abnormalities predominantly located in the outer third of the lung, along the pleural surfaces. Characteristic of organizing pneumonia, UIP, and chronic eosinophilic pneumonia.

entries.title: Pleural Calcification
entries.content: Calcification within the pleural layers. May be focal or diffuse. Causes include asbestos exposure, empyema, TB, and hemothorax. Bilateral pleural plaques suggest asbestos.

entries.title: Pleural Plaque
entries.content: Discrete area of pleural thickening, usually on parietal pleura. Frequently calcified. Bilateral plaques are highly specific for asbestos exposure.

entries.title: Pleural Tail Sign
entries.content: Linear opacity extending from a pulmonary nodule to the pleura. Suggests malignancy but not specific. Also called pleural tag.

entries.title: Pneumatocele
entries.content: Thin-walled, gas-filled space in the lung parenchyma, usually developing after infection (especially staphylococcal pneumonia) or trauma. Typically resolves spontaneously.

entries.title: Posterior Recess
entries.content: The posterolateral portion of the costophrenic sulcus where small pleural effusions first accumulate. Most dependent part of pleural space when supine.

entries.title: Progressive Massive Fibrosis (PMF)
entries.content: Conglomerate upper lobe masses in coal worker's pneumoconiosis and silicosis. Formed by coalescence of nodules. May have calcification and cavitation.

entries.title: Pseudocavitation
entries.content: Small air-containing cystic spaces within a ground-glass nodule representing uninvolved lung or dilated bronchioles. Seen in adenocarcinoma with lepidic growth.

entries.title: Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension
entries.content: Elevated pulmonary artery pressure. CT signs include main PA diameter >29mm, PA:Aorta ratio >1, right heart enlargement, and mosaic attenuation.

entries.title: Pulmonary Ligament
entries.content: Double layer of pleura extending from the hilum to the diaphragm. Contains inferior pulmonary vein. Inferior pulmonary ligament nodal station (9).

entries.title: Random Distribution
entries.content: Nodules distributed without respect to pulmonary lobular structures or lymphatic pathways. Suggests hematogenous spread. Seen in miliary TB and metastases.

entries.title: Reticulation
entries.content: Network pattern of innumerable interlacing lines on CT. Indicates interstitial thickening. May be fine (early fibrosis) or coarse (established fibrosis).

entries.title: Ring Shadow
entries.content: Circular or ring-like opacity representing a bronchiectatic airway seen end-on. The signet ring sign is a variant where the ring is next to a smaller dot (artery).

entries.title: Rounded Atelectasis
entries.content: Atelectasis appearing as a round or oval mass-like opacity, usually adjacent to pleural disease. Classic comet-tail sign of vessels and bronchi curving into the mass.

entries.title: S Sign of Golden
entries.content: Central mass causing collapse of right upper lobe, with concave lateral margin of the collapsed lobe and convex medial margin from the mass. Classic for central lung cancer.

entries.title: Saber-Sheath Trachea
entries.content: Trachea with decreased coronal diameter and increased sagittal diameter (coronal:sagittal ratio <0.6). Associated with COPD.

entries.title: Satellite Nodules
entries.content: Small nodules surrounding a larger nodule or mass. May indicate benign granulomatous disease (TB, fungal) or multifocal malignancy.

entries.title: Septal Lines
entries.content: Linear opacities representing thickened interlobular septa. Kerley A and B lines on radiography. On CT, seen as a network of lines at the lung periphery.

entries.title: Signet Ring Sign
entries.content: Cross-sectional appearance of dilated bronchus (ring) adjacent to its accompanying pulmonary artery (dot), with bronchus larger than artery. Diagnostic for bronchiectasis.

entries.title: Silhouette Sign
entries.content: Loss of normal interface between structures of similar density. Indicates pathology in the same plane. Classic example: RML pneumonia obscures right heart border.

entries.title: Solid Component
entries.content: The portion of a part-solid nodule that completely obscures underlying structures, best measured on mediastinal window. Size of solid component determines malignancy risk.

entries.title: Split Pleura Sign
entries.content: Enhancement of separated visceral and parietal pleura with fluid between them. Indicates empyema. The pleural layers enhance due to inflammation.

entries.title: Subcarinal Space
entries.content: Mediastinal space below the carina between the main bronchi. Contains subcarinal lymph nodes (station 7). Enlargement indicates adenopathy.

entries.title: Subpleural
entries.content: Located immediately beneath and parallel to the pleural surface. Subpleural distribution is characteristic of UIP, asbestosis, and some infectious processes.

entries.title: Subpleural Curvilinear Line
entries.content: Thin curvilinear opacity within 1cm of and parallel to the pleural surface. Indicates early fibrosis or gravity-dependent atelectasis.

entries.title: Subsolid Nodule
entries.content: Pulmonary nodule with less than completely solid attenuation. Includes pure ground-glass nodules and part-solid nodules. Higher likelihood of adenocarcinoma spectrum.

entries.title: Target Sign
entries.content: Nodule with central low attenuation and peripheral rim, resembling a target. May be seen in metastases, septic emboli, and some granulomatous diseases.

entries.title: Thoracic Inlet
entries.content: The superior opening of the thorax bounded by T1 vertebra, first ribs, and manubrium. Important landmark for thyroid and vascular pathology.

entries.title: Tracheal Bronchus
entries.content: Anomalous bronchus arising from trachea above the carina, usually supplying the right upper lobe apical segment. Usually asymptomatic anatomic variant.

entries.title: Tram Track Sign
entries.content: Parallel linear opacities representing dilated bronchus seen along its length. A sign of bronchiectasis. Named for resemblance to railroad tracks.

entries.title: Tree-in-Bud Pattern
entries.content: Centrilobular branching linear opacities with nodular tips resembling a budding tree. Represents bronchiolar impaction with inflammatory or infectious material.

entries.title: UIP Pattern
entries.content: Usual Interstitial Pneumonia pattern on CT: subpleural, basal predominant reticulation with honeycombing and traction bronchiectasis. Diagnostic pattern for IPF.

entries.title: Varicose Bronchiectasis
entries.content: Bronchiectasis with alternating areas of dilation and constriction giving a beaded appearance. Intermediate severity between cylindrical and cystic bronchiectasis.

entries.title: Volume Doubling Time (VDT)
entries.content: Time required for a nodule to double in volume (equivalent to 26% increase in diameter). VDT <400 days suggests malignancy; >600 days suggests benign.

entries.title: Volume Loss
entries.content: Reduction in lung volume indicated by fissural displacement, mediastinal shift, elevation of hemidiaphragm, and crowding of pulmonary vessels. Seen in atelectasis and fibrosis.

entries.title: Westermark Sign
entries.content: Focal area of decreased pulmonary vascularity distal to a pulmonary embolism. Results from oligemia in the affected segment. Can be subtle on CT.

entries.title: Windmill Sign
entries.content: Appearance of multiple dilated bronchi radiating from the hilum in severe bronchiectasis, resembling windmill blades. Indicates severe airways disease.
